intro: Digitalis miniana, commonly known as the lesser foxglove, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and features upright stems covered in fine, hairy foliage. The plant produces clusters of bell-shaped flowers, usually in shades of pink or purple, which bloom from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are oval and slightly wrinkled, with a distinctive grayish-green color. Digitalis miniana is part of the Plantaginaceae family and is valued for its ornamental appeal in gardens.
